content.webTitle: Morning Mail: Direct Action and other budget blockers; Foley suspect

fields.headline: Morning Mail: Direct Action and other budget blockers; Foley suspect
fields.bodyText: Good morning folks, and welcome to the Morning Mail – sign up here to get it straight to your inbox before 8am every weekday. James Foley Security services are close to identifying the British man suspected of beheading the American journalist James Foley, according to the British ambassador to the US. A second American journalist, Peter Theo Curtis, has been released by Jabhat al-Nusra, an affiliate of al-Qaida in Syria. Islamic State militants have seized a Syrian airbase and tightened their hold on a community north of Baghdad. We have a special report from the frontline with the controversial Shia militia taking the war to Islamic State in Iraq. Budget blockers The government has ramped up its threats to increase taxes if the Senate keeps blocking budget savings, as measures worth $3.5bn look set to face stiff opposition this week. Extensive amendments to the Coalition’s Direct Action climate plan being proposed by Nick Xenophon could bring it within reach of meeting Australia’s 2020 emissions reduction target – if the government accepts them. Education minister Christopher Pyne said universities could face cuts to research funding if higher education reforms do no pass the Senate, and called on student protesters to “get some perspective” because the government is “not exactly asking for their left kidney”. Lenore Taylor writes on how the budget sales pitch has changed from charm offensive to passive aggression. Australian news and sport • Victorian doctors have backed the state Labor leader in calling for medical marijuana to be trialled with a view to legalisation. • A Queensland couple who died on MH17 have been identified as Howard and Susan Horder, both 63 and from Brisbane. • Australian F1 driver Daniel Ricciardo has won the Belgian Grand Prix. • The All Blacks dished out a monstering at Eden Park this weekend, and the screams of the Wallabies will haunt Australian rugby for years to come, says Rajiv Maharaj. Around the world • Libya’s capital is under the control of Islamist-led militias who have proclaimed their own government after fierce fighting. • Veteran actor Richard Attenborough has died aged 90; we’ll have more on his life throughout the day. • Three people have been critically injured and 87 sent to hospital after a magnitude 6.0 earthquake hit California. • Iran claims it has downed a stealth drone belonging to Israel at a nuclear facility. • Ukraine has marked Independence Day with a parade of soldiers and heavy weaponry through Kiev. • A volcanic eruption beneath a glacier in Iceland has prompted authorities to raise the aviation warning code to red, warning of an imminent eruption. More from around the internet • Among the most viewed on the Guardian this morning: an interview with Robert Lustig, the scientist who says sugar is poison. • More than 50 refugees resettled by Australia on Nauru say they have been “abandoned to live like animals in the jungle”, Fairfax reports. • Australian Laura Bushney claims she was sexually assaulted by a senior Malaysia Airlines staff member while on board a flight from Kuala Lumpur to Paris, 7News reports. • Denis Napthine’s Coaltion is facing electoral wipeout in Victoria according to the latest Newspoll, the Australian reports. • Australian houses are overvalued by 20-30%, leaving the country vulnerable to a big international economic shock, the AFR reports. One last thing The Leica camera is 100 years old: here’s John Naughton on why he loves it. Have an excellent day – and if you spot anything I’ve missed, let me know in the comments here or on Twitter @newsmary.
